After facing several club-level opponents, the International Boxing Club guaranteed Louis $300,000 to face undefeated heavyweight contender [[Rocky Marciano]] on October 26, 1951.<ref name=si1985/> Despite his being a 6-to-5 favorite, few boxing insiders believed Louis had a chance.<ref>http://www.eastsideboxing.com/boxing-news/mccoy2404.php</ref> Marciano himself was reluctant to participate in the bout, but was understanding of Louis's position: "This is the last guy on earth I want to fight."<ref>{{cite web |last=Levine |first=Ben |url=http://media.www.muhlenbergweekly.com/media/storage/paper300/news/2008/10/23/Sports/Over-The.Ropes-3506639.shtml |title=Over the ropes |work=The Muehlenberg (College) Weekly |date=October 23, 2008}}</ref> It was feared, particularly among those who had witnessed Marciano's punching power first hand, that Louis's unwillingness to quit would result in serious injury. Fighting back tears, [[Ferdie Pacheco]] said in the ''[[SportsCentury]]'' documentary about his bout with Marciano, "He [Louis] wasn't just going to lose. He was going to take a vicious, savage beating. Before the eyes of the nation, Joe Louis, an American hero if ever there was one, was going to get beaten up." But the legs were no longer there for a long grueling fight to overcome Marciano's ferocity. Louis was dropped in the eighth round by a Marciano left, and knocked out of the ring less than thirty seconds later.
